utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, seem to be doing that a lot, lately. People keep living because of my mistakes.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Progression of the paralysis pretty much confirms Hamilton was right. It’s ALS.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Assuming this is a progression of his paralysis.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He can’t move his arm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes, his arm is paralyzed. Yes, his legs are paralyzed. Why is everyone so gung-ho to connect those two conditions? You could think I’m wrong, but that’s no reason to stop thinking?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How about this one? He’s not our patient.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope, not good enough.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He could have suffered a stroke when he was intubated. Well, blood clots are common in intubated patients. The inactivity causes –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not interested in why. Let’s get an MR-angiogram for an embolic stroke.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He doesn’t want you treating him!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They dropped the court order.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah, and that girl dropped the charges against Kobe. Doesn’t mean that he should call her and see if she’s free to get a sundae.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good point, but I can go within 50 feet of him now.

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: If you need anything, page me. Any time.

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: Okay. Get outta here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure. That makes sense. You hate me for saving your life. In fairness to your side, you were also dying because of me, so –

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: You know I didn’t wanna be saved.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s what’s interesting. Your thyroid was low, but not low enough to cause depression.

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: So, you came here to tell me that even if I can’t walk I can still hear the birds sing? Enjoy the rainbow, and feeling the sun shine on my face?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Those things are fun. Okay, life sucks. Your life sucks more than most. It’s not as bad as some, which is depressing all by itself. But do me a favor. Just let me find out what’s wrong with you. And if you still want to kill yourself, I’ll give you a hand. That sound fair?

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: Yeah, sure. I’ll stick around to indulge your obsession. It’s over. I lost my air. The session the other night, with those kids? That was a test to see if I could still play. I can’t.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And that’s all you are? A musician?

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: I got one thing, same as you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Really? Apparently, you know me better than I know you.

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: I know that limp. I know the empty ring finger. And that obsessive nature of yours, that’s a big secret. You don’t risk jail and your career just to save somebody who doesn’t want to be saved unless you got something, anything, one thing. The reason normal people got wives and kids and hobbies, whatever. That’s because they don’t got that one thing that hits them that hard and that true. I got music, you got this. The thing you think about all the time, the thing that keeps you south of normal. Yeah, makes us great, makes us the best. All we miss out on is everything else. No woman waiting at home after work with the drink and the kiss, that ain’t gonna happen for us.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s why God made microwaves.

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: Yeah, but when it’s over, it’s over.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s not over for me. Either you’re gonna call the cops again, or we’re doing this. If you wanna die, you can do it just as easily inside an MRI machine.

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: So, I go back to L.A. I’m doing the Dana lectures again this year.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Wow. That’s quite an honor.

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: It’s all political.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: To be honest, you’ve earned it.

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: I got lucky on a couple studies I was doing. It all sells tickets. You remember last year’s lectures, don’t you?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I remember the cigar bar afterwards.

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: The only reason to attend the thing: cigars and pool. You enjoy working with Dr. House?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not the word I’d use.

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: We work too hard not to enjoy ourselves, right? Hmm. You seeing anybody?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Kinda sorta.

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: Serious?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I don’t know. Could be.

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: You think she would enjoy L.A.?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hamilton offered me a job.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You gonna take it?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I haven’t decided.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You already have the most prestigious fellowship.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s a partnership. Three times the money, car allowance, moving expense, pension plan, the chance to work for a guy who gives a crap what other people think.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: So, why didn’t you just tell him yes?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I made a commitment here.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Right.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House would let you out of it in a heartbeat.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Or he wouldn’t, just to jerk me around. Would you guys have taken the job?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Don’t need the money.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m not like you. I don’t hate House.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You guys really don’t have a problem with him, with what he did?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He knows we disagree with his choice.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Choice? Chase, it’s not apples and oranges, its right and wrong. And he does it like he doesn’t care! He assaults the guy and moves on to the next differential diagnosis like it’s nothing –

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What do you want from him? More hand-wringing, more torment? You want him to cry himself to sleep at night?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah! Yeah, I want some clue that he knows it’s a big deal. That it scares him, that it matters.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Whoa, whoa, whoa, what’s that?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It was a stroke!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Well done, Cameron.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House called it. The arm and legs are unrelated.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You make enough calls, one of them is bound to be right.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yeah, he’s just a lucky, lucky guy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Listen, listen, I just think it wouldn’t hurt him to learn a little humility.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, what’s the verdict?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Embolus. The arm problem’s caused by a clot.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: There’s a good chance we can still bust the clot with tPA.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do it. See what happens to his arm.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We found a blood clot in your brain. We’d like to start you on heparin, it’s a blood thinner.

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: What are the side effects?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well, your lungs are kind of chewed up from the pneumonia. Good chance there’ll be an effusion.

utterance.speaker: Cora
utterance.content: Bleeding?

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: Into his lungs.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s our best chance to give you back the use of your arm.

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: I don’t need my arm without my air.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The damage would likely be minimal.

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: It’s his call.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Or we could do an embolectomy. Basically, we’d go in and pull the clot out.

utterance.speaker: Cora
utterance.content: He’s saying no to drugs and you’re recommending brain surgery?

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: Bypasses risk to the lungs.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’ll either help your arm, or –

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: Or it’ll kill me.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: From your point of view, it’s a win-win.

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We’ll set up the procedure for today.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’re in your carotid artery. This is going to take us all the way up into your brain.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You all right?

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The sludge is blocking the blood flow to the part of the brain that controls your arm. All done. You still okay?

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: I think so.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I don’t know, I guess… It’s just with Dr. Hamilton here, I notice a difference in styles.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: His style involves humility. Another difference in our styles: I don’t care much for apologies. You can go.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I didn’t know you were standing there when I said that, okay? It was completely rude.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do you mean genuine humility? You know, with all the self-doubt and the self-questioning, or Hamilton’s polite, patronizing “Aw, shucks” humility?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’re both excellent doctors.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thank you. And humility is an important quality. Especially if you’re wrong a lot.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’ve been wrong every step of the way.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Of course, when you’re right, self-doubt doesn’t help anybody, does it? We gotta go.

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: Congratulations, Gregg.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Congratulations… Why, Marty?

utterance.speaker: Cora
utterance.content: John woke up, he can use his arm.

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: Now look, I know we’ve had our differences, but I think when a person does something well it ought to be recognized.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The phone works. Next time you want to make me feel all warm and fuzzy, leave a message. Don’t get me wrong, I’m overcome with joy.

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: Doc?

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: Yeah?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: You just touched my leg.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What, you gonna charge me with assault again?

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: No, I felt it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He now has feeling all the way up to calf. This is the way medicine evolved. Patients sometimes get better. You have no idea why, but unless you give a reason they won’t pay you. Anybody notice if there’s a full moon?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You’re saying he just spontaneously got better?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, I’m saying let’s rule out the lunar god and go from there.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Something he’s on is working.

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: The enzyme replacement protocol is working, reversing the ALS.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The timing doesn’t seem suspicious to you?

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: Heh heh, do you think Dr. House will see it that way? Figure it’s his medication doing the job?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’m sure he will.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s one of ours.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: How do we figure out which drug is doing the trick?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Easy. We stop all of them.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: One of those drugs is helping him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And the rest? Steroids, antibiotics, anti-inflammatories, they’re toxic if we leave him on all of them.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He’ll walk again.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, to his own funeral.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: But if we stop everything, he’ll get worse.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: True. And then we’ll add our medications back, one at a time. If he gets better, then we’ll have our answer.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: And if he doesn’t get better?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then we’re in trouble. Not as much as he is. I suppose that was your point.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I assume you want me to convince Hamilton to stop his treatments, too?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don’t care.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You know at least five of the medications are part of his protocol?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If his stuff was helping the guy would be playing tennis six months ago. It’s our round of treatment that’s helping.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Right. So that’s what you’ll stop.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: So your philosophy is, “If they don’t want treatment, they get it shoved down their throat, but if it might cure their paralysis, whoa, better slow down.”

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. My old philosophy used to be “Live and let live,” but I’m taking this needlepoint class and they gave us these really big pillows.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What’s your philosophy on employee relations?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s a very tiny pillow.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Great. Sounds like you know what you’re doing.

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: Gregg. Can I have a word?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Can it wait for the commercial, Marty? Say “hi” to my friend, Jimmy.

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: Pleasure. Your diagnostic trial –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Seriously, commercial’s in about five minutes.

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: -- it’s a dangerous game.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Only if we’re watching in the bathtub.

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: I need to know exactly what medications you were giving John Henry.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Forget it. And if Foreman tells you what John Henry used to be on –

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: You’re gonna fire him?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope. Make him live out every day of his two-year contract.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Foreman asked to leave?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not yet.

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: But how do you know I made him an –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re a polite twit, but you’re not an idiot.

utterance.speaker: Hamilton
utterance.content: I need to know what medications you’ve taken him off of.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wait a second. You’re not an idiot. You need to know what medications I’ve stopped, because…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He’s getting worse. Right now you still work for me. Come on!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No feeling, no wiggling. The bad news is, John Henry’s back where he started. The good news is, Hamilton looks bad.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah, it’s not whether you win or lose, it’s whether the other guy loses.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What was the first thing we put him on?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Steroids, for the pneumonia.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, put him back on them. Give them 24 hours, see what happens.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: His lungs aren’t great. It might cause another respiratory collapse.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure hope not. I didn’t much like that lawyer. And get an MRI.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He already got one. And an MRA.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, obviously something is different now. Do it again. Chase, take care of the scan. Cameron, put him on the steroids. We should probably talk, huh?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Thin cuts.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What levels?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: T9 through the quarter-equinus, same as the last time. You really think House would let Foreman out of his contract?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He has to. If he doesn’t, he’s telling Foreman he needs him. House can’t handle that. Oh, my God!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I checked him out. He’s a great doctor. You think he’s better than I am?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: This about your ego?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Answer the question. It’s not going to change my opinion of myself. Might affect my opinion of you, but that shouldn’t affect your opinion of yourself. Now I’m getting confused. If you think he’s a better doctor than I am, then you should take the job. Otherwise, you should get him to buy you two or three more nostalgic lunches and politely decline.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s that simple? I should just ignore the mockery and abuse?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, how do I abuse you?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How do you not? If I make a mistake –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I hold you accountable, so what?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Dr. Hamilton forgives. He’s capable of moving on.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That is not what he does!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I screwed up his case, he told me –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He never said you were forgiven. I was there, he said it wasn’t your fault.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, it was. You took a chance, you did something great. You were wrong, but it was still great. You should feel great that it was great. You should feel like crap that it was wrong. That’s the difference between him and me. He thinks you do your job, and what will be, will be. I think that what I do and what you do matters. He sleeps better at night. He shouldn’t.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Arteriovenous malformation.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Intradural, compressing his spine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Causing his paralysis.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How could Hamilton have missed an AVM?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, we missed it, too. ‘Cause it wasn’t there before.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You saying it just grew overnight?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. It was on the spine, it wasn’t on the MRI. Same anatomic location.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s not there.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, what is there?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Nothing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or something that looks like nothing.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Background noise, static.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Scar tissue? Inflammation?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: If it’s inflammation, the steroids would have shrunk it down.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Revealing the AVM, which has always been there, hiding behind its own swelling. We remove that, he’ll walk again.

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: Dr. House! Cora’s meeting me outside with a limo. I’m being discharged.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fifty bucks says I can beat you to the curb.

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: Thanks for sticking with the case.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I can’t do anything else. You’re much more easily amused when you can walk.

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: How bizarre. I’m guessing you weren’t exactly Mr. Sunshine even before your leg got messed up. I want you to have this.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wow.

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: You can sell it if you want to, just promise me you won’t play it. How many of those pills you taking?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m in pain.

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: Yeah. Aren’t we all? So, where do you buy these things, do they have cane stores?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, don’t worry about it. You’ll be jogging before you need a second one. See you tomorrow, Eric.
